title: Favorite web comics? (since the old topic was deleted)
content:
So any of you have any favorite web comics?
mines:
Exterminatus now: [url=http://exterminatusnow.keenspace.com/]exterminatusnow.keenspace.com/[/url] (might include some swearing)

VG Cats: [url=http://www.vgcats.com/]www.vgcats.com/[/url] (again might include swearing)

Penny Arcade: [url=http://www.penny-arcade.com]www.penny-arcade.com[/url] (swearing again [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] )

Ctrl-Alt-Del: [url=http://www.ctrlaltdel-online.com/index.php]www.ctrlaltdel-online.com/index.php[/url] (Swearing)

and

Chaos Diamonds 3: [url=http://www.fireball20xl.com/cd3/index.php]www.fireball20xl.com/cd3/index.php[/url] (violence warning)The end is near. An evil force returns. And only Commander Keen can stop him, but this time he must team up with a super sonic hedgehog and a two tailed fox. Follow the adventure:[url=http://www.geocities.com/superadammario/chaos.html]Dimension Chaos[/url]
A Commander Keen and Sonic The Hedgehog Crossover Fan Fiction

Visit my website at [url=http://www.geocities.com/superadammario]www.geocities.com/superadammario[/url]

title: Re: Favorite web comics? (since the old topic was deleted)
content:
Here's mine:
* Dandy and Company: [url=http://dandyandcompany.com]dandyandcompany.com[/url]
* PvP Online: [url=http://pvponline.com]pvponline.com[/url]
* Ctrl-Alt-Delete Comics: see above
* Goodbye, Cruel World!: [url=http://tmst.twu.net]tmst.twu.net[/url] (rarely updated)

And that's it. I used to read some other comics, but they got boring so I stopped reading them.
My [url=http://kevan.org/brain.cgi?grafix5000]MindBending Power[/url] is 5.43 points.
Possibly the [url=http://legion.gibbering.net/misterx/troutwar.php?s=grafix5000]funniest thing[/url] on the interweb.
Go to [url=http://www.toxicsheep.com]www.toxicsheep.com[/url] to see my site!

[img]http://www.toxicsheep.com/sigs/scrobblersig.php[/img]

title: comic!
content:
If you're a Dungeons and Dragons kind of nerd at all, Rich Burlew's Order of the Stick is very funny. http://www.giantitp.com (click on Comics)

It's a ton (and I mean a TON) of backreading, but David Willis spent something like 7 or 8 years writing a webcomic spawned off of the comic he wrote for his school (university?) newspaper. It's Walky! http://www.itswalky.com (the quality of art changes dramatically over the years)

David Willis has started a new comic, after finally ending It's Walky!, which is an elaboration on the comic he did on the side during It's Walky!'s run, entitled Shortpacked. http://www.shortpacked.com (I think--it's changed addresses recently)

If you're one of those anti-Windows anti-Microsoft kind of people, and don't mind really bad (and I mean BAD) art, UserFriendly can be good for a laugh once or twice a week (even though it's a daily comic) http://www.userfriendly.org (I really don't read this one often, but at work I was incredibly bored, so I'd check up on this guy once a month or so)

Finally, I've heard 8-Bit Theatre mentioned a few times, which is over at http://www.nuklearpower.com/latest.php ... but to me it's in the same class as UserFriendly. The characters have all just become too shallow and stereotypical.

Anyway, there's a few others I read, but most of the good ones have all been mentioned already. At the moment, I get the most laughs out of Order of the Stick. It's pretty quality writing, from a D'n'D dork's perspective. :-)[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/posted-pics/XkyRauhKeenLogo.png[/img]

title: Rectangles!
content:
[url=http://www.kidradd.com/]Kid Radd[/url] Concluded last year.
[url=http://www.meninhats.com/]Men In Hats[/url] New instalments are sporadic at the moment.

I'm not that big a fan of web comics, and these are really the only two I've followed.Cave assectatorem Ductoris Alacris

"You are so afraid to live--so afraid of life itself--that you've given up the very nature of your being in trade for security."
-CWG Book 3, Neale Donald Walsh

[url=http://jimsoft.spatang.com/]JimSoft Lair[/url]

(I want to be sold)

title: Re: hehe
content:
Let's see... for me (other than ones already listed), there's gpf-comics.com, tailsteak.tk, www.nedroid.com, and www.theaterhopper.com. I also quite enjoy www.filibustercartoons.com for its political humor (but he lives in the same part of Canada I do, so it makes more sense to me).

I can try... first of all, I didn't mention dandyandcompany.com, because Grafix already did, but that's probably my favorite online comic. It's Looney Tunes inspired, and quite adventurous.

Next, I should also mention that to get a really good feel of an online comic you really gotta go back into the archives and read everything. Because the entire archive of an online comic is available to you, comic strip creators can bring up stuff that happened years ago (which is a lot harder to do in newspaper comics).

Okay, gpf-comics. There's about 7 years of history to this one, so you have to have a lot of time on your hands to read it now, but I think what impresses me most is the mix of characters. Most comic strip characters are just aspects of the character's own personality, but in this comic, the characters feel very different and engaging. It doesn't feel like these characters all came from one man's head. Plus, the main character is a computer geek who's staying pure until marriage... that's personally reassuring. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I found Tailsteak.tk because of a comic strip he did called [url=http://oneoverzero.keenspace.com/]One Over Zero[/url]. If you can get through the first 100 strips, it turns into this really insightful comic strip where the characters are completely aware that they're comic strip characters, and it's a vehicle to start analyzing a lot of complex issues. Once he finished that comic, he made Tailsteak.tk. Half of the stuff on there is ho-hum, but some of it is quite brilliant.

Nedroid.com - not really a comic strip, just a collection of strange and wacky ideas. Some of them are quite funny. (You didn't need convincing on that one.)

TheaterHopper - It's pretty much just a pop-culture comic. Whatever movies are currently in theaters, that's what it comments about (80% of the time, anyways). It's really just an escapism comic for me... I hardly ever go to the movies any more, so it lets me know what I'm missing without shelling out 10 bucks every week.

FilibusterCartoons - This is an online political comic. Something I've observed over the time I've been on the Internet is that the whole Internet is leftist. If it had been up to Internet surfers, George Bush would have probably gotten 2% of the vote (and PLEASE don't turn this topic into a political one just because I said that). So, it's nice to read a political comic written by someone in the same province I live in that takes fun of both sides (even though I'd probably categorize it as slightly right of center).

You'll notice I didn't really mention artistic style in any of these. As much as I like to see beautiful art, that's not what I look for in my online comics. If I'm engaged by the characters and/or humor and it's not crude, I'll probably read it.

(Of course, if you want great art in comics, I seriously suggest you check out www.sketchesandsquirrels.com... now THAT guy knows art.)[url=http://www.screenhog.com]www.screenhog.com[/url]
